sections.text: The aim of this study is to investigate the possibility of automatically identifying abnormalities in tissue samples by using an ensemble model based on data generated by histological examination and minimizing the number of false-negative cases.Keywords - Data Mining, CART, Logistic Regression, Breast Cancer. INTRODUCTIONBreast Cancer Screening is performed to detect cancer cells before a person exhibits symptoms. As part of breast cancer screening, when a lump is found, a fine dust biopsy (FNAB) is performed, a technique widely used in the evaluation of non-palpable breast lesions.

sections.heading: A. Outlier Detection
sections.text: All histological data are of good quality, without missing values or outliers. sections.heading: B. Normality Assumption
sections.text: Before proceeding with the modelling phase, we checked whether the variables met the assumption of normality or not, and this was indeed the case for all variables, as shown in Figure 1. To further guarantee the quality of the data, we calculated the crooked and kurtosis (i.e. peak values) measurements for each variable and confirmed that they were within the interval [- 2 / + 2] that was considered acceptable for such statistics. As reflected in their skew levels, the variables had acceptable symmetries; however, with regard to kurtosis, we had two variables that exceeded this range: area and dimension due to their long tails; a minor problem that was solved with the normalization of the data.

metadata.abstractText: Classification models for the automatic detection of abnormalities on histological samples do exists, with an active debate on the cost associated with false negative diagnosis (underdiagnosis) and false positive diagnosis (overdiagnosis). Current models tend to underdiagnose, failing to recognize a potentially fatal disease. The objective of this study is to investigate the possibility of automatically identifying abnormalities in tissue samples through the use of an ensemble model on data generated by histological examination and to minimize the number of false negative cases.
